results.title: Energy unlimited: nuclear research at Lucas Heights
results.creator_credit: Australian Atomic Energy Commission and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The history of the Atomic Research Establishment at Lucas Heights near Sydney and a description of its work in atomic research and in producing radio-isotopes for industry and medicine. Includes the construction of the buildings; the official opening by the Prime Minister, the Rt. Hon. R.G. Menzies in 1958; the functioning of the research reactor.
results.title_for_label: Energy unlimited: nuclear research at Lucas Heights
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Atomic Energy Commission and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.description: The history of the Atomic Research Establishment at Lucas Heights near Sydney and a description of its work in atomic research and in producing radio-isotopes for industry and medicine. Includes the construction of the buildings; the official opening by the Prime Minister, the Rt. Hon. R.G. Menzies in 1958; the functioning of the research reactor.

results.title: Energy: the problems and the future
results.brief_description: Each of the four basic elements - water, earth, wind and fire of the sun - is a possible energy source for the future. The film shows developments in France with housing designs and tidal power.

results.title: Energy. Ep. 2. The Nuclear alternative
results.creator_credit: George McQuilkin, Anthony Morris, Jane Treiman and Churchill Films
results.brief_description: Explores fission power, how it works and the controversies over safety and radioactive waste. Stresses societies’ need to develop ways of using less energy. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Energy: the fuels and man
results.brief_description: Defines energy and differentiates between renewable fuels. Traces man’s changing use of fuel resources and assesses the strengths and weaknesses of major energy resources used to-day.

results.title: Energy. Ep. 1. The Dilemma
results.brief_description: Discusses past, present and future energy growth patterns. Explores problems of supply and demand, depletion of fossil fuels, our dependency and economic and social problems. Stresses societies’ need to develop ways of using less energy. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: The Energy picture
results.creator_credit: Gerald Potterton, John Halas and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description: The story of man’s use of energy from the days of primitive sun worship to the present time. It took man a long time to find sources of energy - apart from man power - which he could harness to his own ends. For centuries he knew only of the horse, water, wind and fire. Then came coal, the steam engine, the Industrial Revolution, and the internal combustion engine using petrol. Today oil is the greatest source of energy. Commentary by Maurice Denham
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gerald Potterton, John Halas and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films

results.title: Energy. Ep. 3. New sources
results.creator_credit: George McQuilkin, Anthony Morris, Jane Treiman and Churchill Films
results.brief_description: Examines the potential and limits of new technologies, including solar, fusion and geothermal. Presents an argument for developing a variety of options. Stresses societies need to develop ways of using less energy. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Energy in perspective
results.creator_credit: Peter De Normanville, Douglas Gordon and Balfour Films
results.brief_description: Looks at the history of energy sources, the effect the industrial revolution had on the use of energy in all forms, its increasing use today, the need for conservation of power sources and the research being undertaken today in all parts of the world into new sources of energy

results.title: Chemical reactions I
results.creator_credit: Barrie Whatley, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description: Discusses the vibration and dissociation of a diatomic molecule. From these simple systems the theoretical ideas that are used to discuss the role of energy in chemical reactions are developed.
